awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Neurological Role of Cartographic Visual Contrast in Geospatial Cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
The use of maps is commonplace in many aspects of daily life given the widespread use of mobile devices for navigation and increased availability of geospatial data on web platforms. It is important to understand how to design maps that communicate information effectively and have high usability. This project studies how map design affects the ability to understand the spaces and places represented in maps via fMRI brain scanning – a method used to see responses in our brains while looking at maps. This project uses brain scanning to better observe and study how the design of maps affects the spatial decision-making process in our minds. Ultimately, the insight from this research has the potential to change how maps are designed and tailored for different applications. This project will contribute to training of graduate students in geospatial design and cognitive science.

Map makers and researchers argue that cartographic visual contrast, the measure of how objects on a map stand out, is important for ensuring that maps are easily read and understood. However, there is no consensus on how to designing maps with good contrast. This matter is complicated by different interpretations of visual contrast in map design. This research uses neuroscientific understandings to reframe visual contrast theories by conducting a traditional map design interaction study coupled with an fMRI brain scanning experiment. Participants’ brain activities are observed while they complete map interaction tasks under different visual contrast conditions. Data are analyzed to identify the areas of the brain relevant for different map interaction tasks. The analysis searches for any potential mediating effects resulting from different map visual contrast conditions. The result of this research helps to modernize and anchor an important map design concept within current design science literature. This also research expands what we know about parts of the brain that are important for map interaction.

por.por_cntn:
This research project investigated the impact of varying visual contrast of lightness and hue in cartographic symbolization on geospatial mental rotation tasks. ​The study utilized behavioral experiments and fMRI neuroimaging methodologies to explore how different levels of visual contrast affect individuals' ability to perform map mental rotation tasks and identified associated brain activation patterns. ​ The outcomes of the project confirmed that visual contrast significantly influences a map reader's ability to make spatial judgments, impacting response time and accuracy. ​ The research emphasized the importance of considering both hue and lightness contrast together in map design to enhance user performance and map legibility. ​ The project's findings contribute to advancing knowledge in the fields of cartography and cognitive neuroscience, paving the way for future investigations into the complex interplay between visual contrast, brain activation, and map reading performance. ​

The project outcomes have implications for understanding how individuals with different levels of geographical knowledge process spatial information, which can inform educational practices and cognitive research. ​ By identifying the impact of visual contrast on geospatial mental rotation tasks, the research provides insights into how map design can be optimized to enhance user experience and cognitive processing. ​ The findings also contribute to the broader field of cognitive neuroscience by elucidating the neural mechanisms involved in geospatial cognition tasks. ​ The interdisciplinary collaboration between cartography, psychology, and neuroscience showcased in the project highlights the value of combining different scientific approaches to gain a comprehensive understanding of complex cognitive processes. ​

By investigating how visual contrast affects geospatial mental rotation tasks, this research underscores the importance of considering diverse user needs and cognitive abilities in map design. ​ This emphasis on inclusivity can lead to the development of more accessible and user-friendly cartographic products that cater to a wider range of individuals. Additionally, the project outcomes have the potential to inform policy decisions related to spatial cognition and map design, influencing practices in fields such as education, urban planning, and environmental management.

In summary, this research project has significantly advanced knowledge in the fields of cartography, cognitive neuroscience, and psychology by elucidating the role of visual contrast in geospatial mental rotation tasks.​ The findings have practical implications for improving map design, enhancing spatial cognition skills, and promoting interdisciplinary collaboration in scientific research. ​
